questiontext.text:
2. Based on a number of strength tests, it is found from the test results that the average strength of a material is 62 N/mm2, and the standard deviation of the measured strength is 14 N/mm2.

Assuming the strength follows normal distribution, determine the minimum number of tests we would have to perform such that we can construct a 95% confidence interval on the expected strength of the material with a width less than 6.2 N/mm2 (i.e. 10% of the average measured strength 62 N/mm2).


Answer:
Minimum number of tests required: {1:NUMERICAL:=79:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

generalfeedback.text:
The 95% confidence interval on the true strength μ can then be determined as:
$$ \small \bar{X} \pm 1.96 \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} $$
Hence, the width of the 95% confidence interval is:
$$ \small 2(1.96) \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} $$
And it is required that:
$$ \small 2(1.96) \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} \leq 0.1 \bar{X}$$
$$ \small \Rightarrow n \geq \left( \frac{2(1.96)\sigma}{0.1\bar{X}} \right)^2 = 78.35$$
Hence, the minimum number of tests is 79.

Assuming the strength follows normal distribution, determine the minimum number of tests we would have to perform such that we can construct a 95% confidence interval on the expected strength of the material with a width less than 6.1 N/mm2 (i.e. 10% of the average measured strength 61 N/mm2).


Answer:
Minimum number of tests required: {1:NUMERICAL:=42:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

generalfeedback.text:
The 95% confidence interval on the true strength μ can then be determined as:
$$ \small \bar{X} \pm 1.96 \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} $$
Hence, the width of the 95% confidence interval is:
$$ \small 2(1.96) \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} $$
And it is required that:
$$ \small 2(1.96) \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} \leq 0.1 \bar{X}$$
$$ \small \Rightarrow n \geq \left( \frac{2(1.96)\sigma}{0.1\bar{X}} \right)^2 = 41.3$$
Hence, the minimum number of tests is 42.

Assuming the strength follows normal distribution, determine the minimum number of tests we would have to perform such that we can construct a 95% confidence interval on the expected strength of the material with a width less than 6.3 N/mm2 (i.e. 10% of the average measured strength 63 N/mm2).


Answer:
Minimum number of tests required: {1:NUMERICAL:=25:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

generalfeedback.text:
The 95% confidence interval on the true strength μ can then be determined as:
$$ \small \bar{X} \pm 1.96 \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} $$
Hence, the width of the 95% confidence interval is:
$$ \small 2(1.96) \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} $$
And it is required that:
$$ \small 2(1.96) \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} \leq 0.1 \bar{X}$$
$$ \small \Rightarrow n \geq \left( \frac{2(1.96)\sigma}{0.1\bar{X}} \right)^2 = 24.78$$
Hence, the minimum number of tests is 25.

Assuming the strength follows normal distribution, determine the minimum number of tests we would have to perform such that we can construct a 95% confidence interval on the expected strength of the material with a width less than 5.6 N/mm2 (i.e. 10% of the average measured strength 56 N/mm2).


Answer:
Minimum number of tests required: {1:NUMERICAL:=18:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

generalfeedback.text:
The 95% confidence interval on the true strength μ can then be determined as:
$$ \small \bar{X} \pm 1.96 \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} $$
Hence, the width of the 95% confidence interval is:
$$ \small 2(1.96) \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} $$
And it is required that:
$$ \small 2(1.96) \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} \leq 0.1 \bar{X}$$
$$ \small \Rightarrow n \geq \left( \frac{2(1.96)\sigma}{0.1\bar{X}} \right)^2 = 17.64$$
Hence, the minimum number of tests is 18.

2. Based on a number of strength tests, it is found from the test results that the average strength of a material is 65 N/mm2, and the standard deviation of the measured strength is 6 N/mm2.

Assuming the strength follows normal distribution, determine the minimum number of tests we would have to perform such that we can construct a 95% confidence interval on the expected strength of the material with a width less than 6.5 N/mm2 (i.e. 10% of the average measured strength 65 N/mm2).


Answer:
Minimum number of tests required: {1:NUMERICAL:=14:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

generalfeedback.text:
The 95% confidence interval on the true strength μ can then be determined as:
$$ \small \bar{X} \pm 1.96 \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} $$
Hence, the width of the 95% confidence interval is:
$$ \small 2(1.96) \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} $$
And it is required that:
$$ \small 2(1.96) \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} \leq 0.1 \bar{X}$$
$$ \small \Rightarrow n \geq \left( \frac{2(1.96)\sigma}{0.1\bar{X}} \right)^2 = 13.09$$
Hence, the minimum number of tests is 14.
